segments.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yatthimā mahānadiyo saṃsandanti samenti, seyyathidaṃ—
segments.en: “Mendicants, there are places where the great rivers—the Ganges, Yamuna, Aciravatī, Sarabhū, and Mahī—come together and converge.

segments.pli: gaṅgā, yamunā, aciravatī, sarabhū, mahī, tato puriso dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni uddhareyya.
segments.en: Suppose a person was to draw two or three drops of water from such a place.

segments.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ—yāni dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni ubbhatāni, yaṃ vā sambhejjaudakan”ti?
segments.en: Which is more: the two or three drops drawn out or the water in the confluence?”

segments.pli: “Etadeva, bhante, bahutaraṃ, yadidaṃ—saṃbhejjaudakaṃ; appamattakāni dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni ubbhatāni.
segments.en: “Sir, the water in the confluence is certainly more. The two or three drops drawn out are tiny.

segments.pli: Saṅkhampi na upenti, upanidhampi na upenti, kalabhāgampi na upenti saṃbhejjaudakaṃ upanidhāya dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni ubbhatānī”ti.
segments.en: Compared to the water in the confluence, it can’t be reckoned or compared, it’s not even a fraction.”
“In the same way, for a noble disciple …
That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sections.title: “Mendicants, there are places where the great rivers—the Ganges,…

suttaplex.blurb: As a few drops of water compared to the confluence of great rivers, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.
